title: Domain 2.3: Compare and contrast protocols for wireless networking.
content:
📶 2.3 – Wireless Protocols & Technologies

📡 Frequencies: 2.4GHz vs. 5GHz

▪️ 2.4GHz

Longer range
Slower speeds
More interference (shared with Bluetooth, microwaves)

▪️ 5GHz

Shorter range
Faster speeds
More channels, less interference

🧠 Exam Tip: If a user needs better speed in the same room → 5GHz. If they need longer coverage through walls → 2.4GHz

🔢 Channels

Frequencies are divided into channels.

  • 2.4GHz = 11 channels (but only 1, 6, 11 are non-overlapping in U.S.)
  • 5GHz = 23+ channels, mostly non-overlapping

🧠 Tip: Channel overlap causes signal interference. Use non-overlapping channels in shared buildings.

🔵 Bluetooth

Short-range wireless (~10 meters). Used for headsets, file transfer, keyboard/mouse.

🧠 Uses 2.4GHz and frequency hopping to avoid interference

🧠 Tip: Know which support dual-band (n, ax), and which are 5GHz-only (a, ac)

📍 Long-Range Fixed Wireless

  • Licensed: Must register with regulators (FCC in U.S.), less interference
  • Unlicensed: Open to public (e.g., 2.4GHz), more interference

Power: Limited by law—too much = fines
Regulatory Requirements: Ensure proper use of spectrum, avoid interference

🧠 Tip: Used in rural areas, campus buildings, or point-to-point setups

📲 NFC (Near-Field Communication)

Ultra short-range (≤4 cm). Used for tap-to-pay, ID badges, transit cards. Works by inductive coupling.

🧠 Tip: Compare to Bluetooth: NFC is faster to connect but works at a much shorter range.

📻 RFID (Radio-Frequency Identification)

Uses radio waves to identify tags or devices. Common in:

  • Inventory tracking
  • Toll tags
  • Access cards

🧠 Tip: Passive RFID = no battery, powered by reader. Active RFID = has its own power source

✅ Exam Quick Hits

  • 2.4GHz = long range, slow, interference
  • 5GHz = fast, short range, more channels
  • Channels 1/6/11 = non-overlapping on 2.4GHz
  • n, ac, ax = fast Wi-Fi, support dual-band
  • NFC = tap to pay, RFID = scan to track
